Our own records show that many of these young
people have failed in other attempts to prepare
themselves for adult responsibility. We have
been coping with the "matriculated" drop-out
from MDTA programs, from State Employment
Training programs. So we have had those ex¬
periences. Now, we must do more than attempt
to capture the interest and imagination of the
poverty population. We must, in fact, achieve
that. We must become consciously aware of the
total educational, psychological, and social
reinforcement "mix." The materials we develop,
therefore, must do more than merely provide
textual frames of reference, they must challenge
and inspire, capture the imagination of these
young people, and engage it actively. Every piece
of information should be conceived as "open-
ended," to allow for the exercise of "original"
thought. Information should provoke, not be mere¬
ly provocative. Materials must be designed to
evoke responses because these young people should
be taught to have respect for their intellectual
capabilities.
